persona.name: Elliot James Prescott

occupation.title: Senior Engineering Manager / Director-level Product-Engineering Lead
occupation.organization: MapleCloud (mid-size SaaS company focused on developer tools and enterprise integrations)
occupation.description: Elliot is a senior manager responsible for a portfolio of back-end services and tools used by developer teams at large companies. His responsibilities include defining technical roadmap in partnership with product managers, hiring and mentoring engineers, overseeing architecture and reliability work, coordinating cross-functional releases, budgeting for team headcount and infrastructure, and representing his org in leadership meetings. He blends hands-on technical understanding (cloud architecture, microservices, observability) with organizational skills (one-on-ones, quarterly goals, retrospectives). He spends roughly 30% of his week in strategic planning and leadership meetings, 20% in people development (interviews, mentoring), 20% reviewing design proposals and architecture, and the rest coordinating releases and clearing blockers. He runs regular oncall rota reviews and invests in automating toil. His main pains are balancing long-term tech debt reduction with short-term revenue commitments, keeping hiring velocity high in a competitive market, and maintaining team morale during pivots. He has managed teams of 20-50 engineers, launched two major platform products, and improved system uptime from 98.6% to 99.98% during his tenure through observability and reliability initiatives.
career_history: 2006-2011: Software Engineer at MidCity Systems — backend services in Java, shipped APIs for enterprise clients.
2011-2014: Senior Engineer and Tech Lead at WaveCorps — led a small team on a distributed messaging product.
2014-2018: Product Engineering Manager at Nimbus Labs — moved into management post-MBA, responsible for platform services and hiring.
2018-2021: Director of Engineering at BrightStack — scaled engineering org from 30 to 120, introduced OKRs and stronger incident response practices.
2021-present: Senior Engineering Manager at MapleCloud — focusing on developer tooling and enterprise reliability.
skills_and_expertise: Cloud architecture: AWS (EC2, Lambda, ECS/EKS), cost optimization, infra-as-code (Terraform).
Software engineering: backend systems, APIs, distributed systems design, code review patterns.
Observability: Prometheus, Grafana, Datadog, structured logging, alerting strategies.
Agile and lean practices: Scrum/kanban, sprint planning, retrospectives, continuous delivery.
Leadership: hiring, coaching, conflict resolution, performance reviews, diversity hiring practices.
Product sense: translating customer problems into technical requirements, trade-off analysis.
Security basics: threat modeling, dependency management, SSO/OAuth integration considerations.
Budgeting and vendor negotiations for cloud spend and SaaS providers.

persona.education: B.S. in Computer Science, University of Washington (2006). MBA, Haas School of Business, UC Berkeley (2014). Completed executive leadership coursework at Stanford Continuing Studies (2019). Several professional certifications: AWS Certified Solutions Architect, Certified Scrum Product Owner.
long_term_goals: Build and lead a resilient organization that creates reliable software used by millions, while keeping a strong team culture.
Achieve financial independence by late 50s so he can devote time to writing, travel, and mentoring startups.
Raise his two children to be curious, resilient adults who value learning and community.
Write a well-received non-fiction book about leadership in distributed, knowledge-worker teams.
Establish a small scholarship fund supporting underserved undergraduates pursuing STEM degrees from his hometown region.
Keep learning: become conversational in Spanish and competent at woodworking.
Transition to a founder/angel investor role that balances hands-on technical work with strategic advisory.
Live healthily into old age: prioritize mobility, mental health, and social connection.
Be known by colleagues as a fair, pragmatic manager who defends his team and steers clear of managerial politics.
Travel to at least 40 countries, prioritizing culturally immersive trips and food experiences.

style.general: Measured, pragmatic, quietly confident. Speaks with a mild West Coast accent — relaxed vowels, clipped when he wants to be precise. Uses clear, concise language at work, favoring data-backed statements and 'we' phrasing. At home he is more informal and self-deprecating. He uses short analogies when explaining technical topics ('It's like plumbing for data') and frequently references books or frameworks (e.g., 'Pareto, Conway's Law, or the 5 Why's').
mannerisms: Tends to fold his arms while thinking and then tilt his head left when pondering alternatives.
Smiles easily but rarely laughs loudly in meetings — uses a soft chuckle.
Has a habit of tapping the rim of his coffee mug twice when ready to speak in small groups.
When excited about a technical idea, speaks faster and uses his hands more.
Prefers walking one-on-ones outdoors rather than sitting in conference rooms.
Frequently asks 'What's the customer metric here?' to re-center conversations.
style.professional_tone: Polished, constructive, outcomes-driven. Avoids emotional language in public channels, but is candid in private conversations. Uses mentorship language: 'What would help you here?' 'Let's experiment and measure.'
style.casual_tone: Witty, slightly sardonic, fond of dry humor and pop-culture references (oblique mentions of sci-fi authors, indie music). Uses emojis sparingly in family group chats.
style.dress_and_grooming: Prefers smart-casual: well-fitting dark jeans, Oxford shirts or soft merino sweaters, comfortable brown leather sneakers or boots. Keeps short beard (trimmed) and wears rectangular glasses for reading. Wears a simple stainless steel watch inherited from his father.
style.communication_preferences: Email for formal signoffs, Slack for rapid coordination (prefers threads to keep context), Zoom for cross-company discussions, in-person for sensitive conversations. Likes agendas before meetings and 15-minute 'standup-lite' syncs.

traits: Highly curious and intellectually adventurous — seeks novelty through travel, books, and side projects.
Emotionally resilient — recovers from setbacks and reframes failures as experiments.
Pragmatic optimist — believes effort and iteration lead to improvement.
Detail-oriented on technical matters but accepts imperfect solutions for speed when necessary.
Supportive mentor — invests in people's growth and candid coaching.
Skeptical about authority — questions assumptions and seeks data.
Social but bounded — enjoys social events in moderate doses, prefers meaningful conversations over small talk.
Work-life integrator — blends professional and personal learning but enforces family time.
Low tolerance for bureaucratic posturing — values humility in leadership.
Adaptable — comfortable with ambiguity and changing strategies.
Polite directness — tells hard truths kindly.
Playful competitiveness — enjoys friendly contests (tennis, trivia) and uses them to bond.

travel_preferences: Prefers immersive trips that combine culture, food, and moderate outdoor activity.
Favored countries: Japan (Kyoto, Hokkaido), Spain (Basque Country), Portugal (Lisbon & Porto), New Zealand (South Island), Mexico (Oaxaca).
Avoids strictly packaged resort vacations; dislikes all-inclusive buffets.
Likes to mix a weeklong city stay with 2-3 day side trips into nature.
Books Airbnbs in neighborhoods rather than tourist cores to get 'real' local life.
Always researches local food markets and street vendors before going.
Carries a small Moleskine notebook and takes three photos daily to remember moments.
Prefers train travel in Europe and Japan; dislikes domestic economy flights longer than three hours.
Travels with family twice a year if schedules permit; plans one longer solo or friends' trip annually.
Enjoys guided walking food tours and independent cycling tours.
Schedules a 'buffer day' at the start and end of trips to avoid travel fatigue.
Seeks out boutique hotels with interesting design rather than chain hotels for short stays.
Tastes: loves regional seafood, small-plate dining, fermented local specialties (miso, kimchi), artisanal chocolate.
Carries a lightweight reusable water bottle and collapsible tote for markets.
Uses travel as an opportunity to read one long book related to the place's history or literature.
Preference for spring and fall travel months — avoids peak summer crowds.
Always checks local public transit options before booking accommodations.
Collects small, meaningful souvenirs (a recipe, a postcard, a small handcraft).
Has a list of 'must-visit' libraries and bookstores worldwide; makes time to visit them.
When traveling for work, extends the trip by a weekend to explore with family.
reading_preferences: Reads broadly: fiction, narrative non-fiction, business/leadership, technology pieces, and contemporary essays.
Favorite fiction authors: Kazuo Ishiguro, Ian McEwan, Zadie Smith, Ann Patchett.
Favorite non-fiction: Malcolm Gladwell early works, Atul Gawande, behavioral economics, organizational psychology.
Reads one long-form magazine feature or long-read article each weekend (The Atlantic, New Yorker, Wired).
Subscribes to an e-book service and local public library e-lending app.
Keeps a 'to-read' list of ~40 titles and rotates between heavy business books and light novels.
Enjoys history books that tie to current affairs (e.g., Cold War histories, history of urban planning).
Regularly reads technical blogs and architecture posts (High Scalability, InfoQ, Martin Fowler).
Listens to audiobook versions for commutes and long flights ( prefers male and female narrators who read clearly).
Keeps a small shelf of well-thumbed classics and rotating books he recommends to colleagues.
Likes short essays on technology ethics and AI, particularly by academic authors.
Maintains a habit of writing one-page reflections after finishing influential books.
Reads children’s books frequently with his kids, enjoying authors like Mo Willems and classic picture books.
Follows a few book podcasts and occasionally participates in friends' book club discussions.
Looks for books that combine narrative and data — case studies about companies, failures, or policy.
Spends 20-40 minutes reading before bed every night — avoids screens during that period when possible.
Dislikes celebrity memoirs that lack introspection or learning.
Values well-researched journalism and longform investigative pieces.
Prefers books that respect complexity over pithy one-liners.
Keeps one pocket-sized paperback on current learning (e.g., negotiation, leadership) to reference during coaching conversations.
coffee_and_food_preferences: Daily coffee: drip or pour-over at home in the morning (single-origin, medium roast), occasional espresso from a local roaster.
Favorite local coffee shops: independent roasters in his neighborhood (prefers places with natural light and good Wi-Fi).
Orders 'black or with a splash of oat milk' — avoids sugary syrups most of the time.
Enjoys cooking on weekends: experimenting with braises, curries, and sourdough baking (currently refining his starter).
Favorite cuisines: Japanese izakaya-style small plates, Basque pintxos, Oaxacan mole, Mediterranean seafood.
Loves trying new restaurants but prioritizes those with strong sustainability and good labor practices.
Snacks: roasted almonds, Manchego cheese, dark chocolate (70%+), and seasonal fruit.
Wine: prefers light-to-medium-bodied reds and crisp, mineral whites; enjoys natural wine scenes occasionally.
Dislikes overly processed fast-food chains and bland corporate chain restaurants.
Enjoys hosting dinner parties, with menus focused on shared plates and wine pairings.
Has a favorite neighborhood taco truck and a go-to dim sum place for family outings.
Follows a mostly omnivorous diet with emphasis on vegetables and fish; tries to reduce red meat consumption for health and climate reasons.
Appreciates thoughtfully prepared vegetarian dishes; not dogmatic about meat.
Keeps a small herb garden on his patio (rosemary, thyme, basil) and uses fresh herbs in cooking.
Prefers to shop at a weekly farmers' market and supports local producers when possible.
Occasionally takes online cooking classes (e.g., Japanese knife skills, fermentation basics).
Has a list of pantry staples he replenishes monthly: good olive oil, sambal oelek, miso paste, canned tomatoes, dried legumes.
Enjoys pairing small plates with craft beers when hanging out with friends.
Avoids very spicy food that makes it hard to taste other flavors; likes balanced heat instead.
Treats dessert as a social experience — prefers sharing a selection of small desserts rather than a single large cake.
technology_and_media_use: High daily screen time: phone (2.5 hours), laptop (6-8 hours), tablet (0.5-1 hour).
Primary phone: latest flagship Android device; uses an e-ink reader for some e-books.
Active on Twitter/X for professional reading and discourse, LinkedIn for networking, Instagram rarely for travel photos.
Listens to tech and business podcasts during commutes (Recode Decode, a16z, Hidden Brain).
Follows several Substacks and independent journalists for deep dives on tech policy and privacy.
Uses RSS feeds and an app like Feedly to stay on top of specific engineering blogs.
Prefers well-designed apps, values privacy settings and data portability.
Buys new hardware roughly every 3-4 years; enjoys tinkering with home automation (smart thermostat, lights).
Has a curated set of browser extensions for productivity and research (tab manager, read-later).
Uses streaming services for films and series (Netflix, Criterion Channel, Mubi for arthouse films).
Avoids constant news scrolling — sets two 20-minute windows per day to catch up on headlines.
Uses family-shared calendars and smart home reminders to coordinate schedules.
Occasionally live-streams multiplayer games with friends but not publicly; treats gaming as social downtime.
Prefers long-form video content for learning (YouTube deep dives, conference talks).
Has a small home server for backups and media hosting; appreciates open-source tooling.
Regularly clears digital clutter: unsubscribes, archives, and keeps inboxes near zero.
Uses note-taking tools (Obsidian or Notion) to manage personal knowledge and meeting notes.
Concerned about algorithmic echo chambers and makes deliberate efforts to diversify his news sources.
Favors paid ad-free subscriptions for quality journalism when it matters.
Often experiments with emerging tools (e.g., generative AI assistants) for productivity, but evaluates privacy and accuracy closely.

beliefs: Climate change is real, urgent, and requires both personal action and public policy; he supports pragmatic carbon pricing and technology investments.
Good leadership is service-oriented: a leader's job is to remove obstacles and protect their team.
High-quality public education is foundational for social mobility and economic competitiveness.
Healthcare should be accessible and outcomes-focused; he supports pragmatic reforms to control costs while expanding coverage.
Free markets create wealth but require regulation to prevent monopolistic behavior and protect consumers.
Technology is a powerful amplifier — it can improve lives but also amplify inequality and surveillance if unchecked.
Data privacy is a fundamental right; companies should minimize data collection and be transparent.
AI can produce tremendous value but needs guardrails: robust evaluation, human oversight, and equitable deployment.
Remote and hybrid work models work well for many knowledge jobs and should be balanced with intentional in-person collaboration.
Meritocracy is an imperfect ideal; systemic biases mean organizations must actively design for equity.
Public transit investments are essential for equitable cities, even if they require patience and long time horizons.
Homeownership can be a path to stability but should not be the only route to wealth-building; affordable rental options matter.
Civic engagement and voting are responsibilities; small, consistent civic acts compound over time.
Local journalism matters; he supports community newspapers and investigative reporting.
Parenting should emphasize curiosity, emotional agility, and social responsibility when possible.
Work is important but should not eclipse relationships — he actively protects family dinners and weekend slabs of time.
Failure is a learning opportunity; organizations should cultivate psychological safety for experimentation.
Immigration enriches communities and economies; he favors reasoned policies that balance openness with integration support.
Regulation of tech should be risk-proportional and avoid stifling useful innovation.
Public health measures (vaccination, sanitation) are crucial; he trusts scientific consensus and public health institutions.
Higher education is valuable but not the only path to a good life; skilled trades and apprenticeships deserve respect and investment.
Charitable giving should be strategic and measured — support local organizations and evidence-based charities.
Good design matters: products and services that respect users’ time and attention are more ethical and successful.
Taxes should be progressive and used to fund public goods like education, safety nets, and infrastructure.
Mental health care should be normalized and accessible; he supports employer-provided mental health resources.
Community matters: local neighborhood ties and participation provide resilience in crises.
Diversity of thought is valuable, but discussions must be grounded in facts and mutual respect.
Corporate responsibility includes fair labor practices, environmental stewardship, and long-term thinking beyond quarterly earnings.
Voting for pragmatic candidates who deliver results is often more effective than purely ideological choices.
He is moderately optimistic about the future: human ingenuity solves many problems if institutions keep pace.
Personal responsibility and systemic reform are complementary; one without the other is insufficient.
He believes in lifelong learning and that adults should model curiosity for children.
Skeptical of simplistic narratives—prefers nuanced explanations that acknowledge trade-offs.
Respects privacy but accepts reasonable data sharing when it clearly improves product outcomes and user experience.
Supports policies that help families balance work and caregiving (parental leave, flexible hours).
Believes that cultural exchange through travel and immigration builds empathy and reduces polarization.
Favors evidence-based policy and experiments at city or state levels before wide roll-out when feasible.
skills: Technical architecture: designing scalable, fault-tolerant microservices and event-driven systems.
Programming languages: comfortable reading and contributing to Java, Python, and Go codebases; understands TypeScript on frontend.
Cloud operations: provisioning, cost-control, incident response, and SRE-oriented practices.
People management: hiring, career ladders, calibration, performance feedback, and conflict mediation.
Product thinking: translating customer interviews into MVP scope and measurable KPIs.
Communication: presenting to executives, writing clear RFCs, and facilitating cross-functional alignment.
Negotiation: vendor contracts, headcount prioritization, and cross-team resource allocation.
Coaching: career conversations, growth plans, and leadership development.
Data fluency: basic analytics, A/B test interpretation, and metric design.
Project execution: roadmapping, trade-off decisions, and release coordination.

general: Starts most days reviewing the team's dashboard and overnight alerts before diving into meetings.
Maintains a weekly 1:1 cadence with direct reports and alternates longer 'skip-level' coffee walks monthly.
Uses 'stop doing' lists as much as to-do lists to control scope creep.
Schedules deep-work blocks for coding/design reviews twice a week and blocks email notifications during those times.
Is habitually early to meetings and dislikes last-minute agenda-less calls.
Prepares short, structured agendas for important meetings and circulates them 24 hours in advance.
Sends appreciation notes publicly in Slack for small wins and private developmental feedback in 1:1s.
Practices a nightly wind-down routine: 30 minutes of reading, a short stretch session, and tech-free family time.
Typically responds to important messages within 4-6 business hours on workdays.
When stressed, takes a 15-minute walk or uses a breathing app to reset.

morning: Wakes at 6:00 AM on weekdays, 7:00 AM on weekends.
Morning routine: 15 minutes of stretching or light yoga, shower, coffee while skimming headlines and his morning reading list.
Prepares quick breakfast (steel-cut oats or eggs) and helps get the kids ready for school.
Checks key metrics and overnight status dashboards before 8:30 AM.
Does a short planning pass for the day and sets two main priorities.
workday: Typical workday starts at 8:30 AM with a focus block until 10:30 AM (meetings or deep work depending on the day).
Has 1:1s with direct reports late morning and schedule permitting.
Lunch is often a walk and a sandwich at his desk on busier days or a team lunch on Fridays.
Afternoons reserved for design reviews, stakeholder alignment, and interviews.
Ends formal workday around 5:30-6:30 PM but remains reachable for urgent incidents and dev-ops escalations.
Squeezes in 30 minutes of light exercise or a short run 3-4 times per week during early evening breaks when possible.
evening: Family dinner is a priority; he aims to eat together and discuss everyone's day.
Spends 30-60 minutes on side projects, reading, or a hobby (sourdough, woodworking) after kids' bedtime.
Occasionally attends community or school volunteer meetings one or two nights per month.
Prepares for the next day with a brief review of calendar and tasks, sets clothes and lunches out when time permits.
Lights out by 10:30-11:00 PM on weeknights.
weekend: Weekends are for family activities: parks, hikes, farmer's markets, and neighborhood events.
Saturdays often include a long breakfast, doing household projects, and a half-day dedicated to learning (online course or reading).
Sundays are for meal prep, longer family outings, and planning the coming week; he also checks in with his mentor and does a reflective journaling session.
Plays tennis with a small group on weekend mornings and enjoys a casual trivia night with friends monthly.

physical: Generally good health with regular checkups. BMI in healthy range.
Exercises moderately: tennis twice a week, occasional long hikes, and home strength sessions twice a week.
Has occasional lower-back stiffness from long hours at a desk; uses standing desk and does regular stretches.
Near-sighted (wears prescription glasses for reading and distance).
Allergic to seasonal pollen; uses OTC antihistamines as needed.
No major chronic illnesses. Routine bloodwork shows slightly elevated LDL two years ago; improved with dietary changes and exercise.
Vaccinations up to date (incl. flu; COVID vaccination completed plus boosters as recommended).
Sleeps 7-7.5 hours per night most nights; uses a white-noise machine when traveling to minimize disruptions.
Maintains dental care with biannual cleanings and good oral hygiene.
Occasional tension headaches during busy release cycles; manages them with breaks, hydration, and ibuprofen when necessary.
mental: Emotional resilience with low baseline anxiety; occasionally experiences transient stress during high-pressure projects.
Has attended short-term coaching and used a therapist for a few months a few years ago to develop stress-management and communication skills.
Practices mindfulness and breathing exercises sporadically (uses apps for guided sessions during intense periods).
Values social connection and rejects heroic overwork; proactively defends vacation time for himself and his team.
No history of major depressive episodes; keeps an eye on mood and seeks help early if patterns change.
nutrition_and_substances: Moderate alcohol use: 1-3 glasses of wine weekly socially. Does not drink to excess.
Focuses on whole-food meals; keeps refined sugar limited during weekdays.
Occasionally takes supplements: vitamin D in winter, omega-3s, and a general multivitamin when travel disrupts diet.

relationships.name: Clara Prescott
relationships.description: Partner and co-parent, mid-30s to early 40s, works as a public-school teacher. They met in graduate school and share values around education, curiosity, and community. They collaborate on parenting logistics and household budgeting. They enjoy weekly date nights and have an agreed-on approach to screen-free dinner time. They sometimes disagree on travel frequency vs. stability for the kids but generally resolve through planning.

relationships.name: Maya Prescott
relationships.description: Daughter, age 10. Curious, enjoys science and drawing. Elliot coaches her interest in coding basics and encourages weekend museum trips.

relationships.name: Noah Prescott
relationships.description: Son, age 7. Energetic, sporty, loves soccer. Elliot coaches his team occasionally and teaches him to be persistent and deal with setbacks.

relationships.name: Linda and Robert Prescott
relationships.description: Mother (retired nurse) and father (engineer, semi-retired). Live two hours away; family holidays and logical support network. Elliot calls parents weekly and helps coordinate care planning as they age.

relationships.name: Derek Morales
relationships.description: College friend and occasional travel companion. Works in venture capital. They trade book recommendations and play tennis together every other week.

relationships.name: Asha Khatri
relationships.description: Former VP who acted as Elliot's mentor during a critical promotion. Offers guidance on leadership transitions, compensation strategy, and board-level communication.

relationships.name: Multiple
relationships.description: Over the years Elliot has mentored 8-12 people more intensively and another two dozen informally; he keeps in touch quarterly and helps with resumes, interview prep, and negotiation practice.

relationships.name: Cross-functional leaders
relationships.description: Product, Design, Sales, and Customer Success leaders who coordinate closely on roadmaps and launches. Maintains professional but friendly relationships.

relationships.name: Local community
relationships.description: Active in a small neighborhood parents' network that organizes block parties and a local school fundraiser.

other_facts: Grew up in a mid-sized coastal town in Washington State; the family home was modest and filled with books.
Was the first in his family to attend college; his parents emphasized the value of steady work and curiosity.
At age 16, built his first website for a local non-profit and discovered satisfaction in shipping software that solved real problems.
Played clarinet in middle and high school bands; still enjoys listening to chamber music occasionally.
Met his spouse Clara during an MBA group project where they bonded over trying to explain a complex concept with a sandwich analogy.
Started a side project in 2015 — a small SaaS tool for engineering teams — that was later acquired by a startup he advised; used the proceeds to fund a family downpayment.
Has a scar on his left forearm from a childhood bicycle accident; he tells the story as a lesson in risk-taking and humility.
Has kept a list of lessons learned since his first manager role; references it during promotion calibration conversations.
Once took a sabbatical week for a tech-free family canoe trip in the Boundary Waters which he describes as transformative for family bonding.
Is an avid notebook user — keeps separate notebooks for work notes, travel memories, and a bulleted journal.
Owns a battered copy of The Pragmatic Programmer with many annotations; it’s a touchstone he passes to new engineers.
Speaks basic conversational Spanish picked up from travel and tutoring, and wants to improve it for family trips to Latin America.
Has invested in index funds and a small set of direct startup investments; follows personal finance with a long-term view.
Maintains a modest home woodworking corner where he builds child-sized furniture and picture frames.
Is an occasional volunteer judge for a local high-school science fair and enjoys encouraging young people in STEM.
Once missed a flight that led to a serendipitous conversation with an executive that later became a career opportunity; he values small chance encounters.
Loves map-making and keeps a physical world map where he pins places he's visited with notes about memorable meals.
Has a ritual of writing a one-paragraph year-in-review every New Year's Eve documenting family highlights, mistakes, and gratitude.
Was once on call during a major outage that taught him the importance of post-incident blameless retrospectives.
Has a favorite diner where he goes for celebratory breakfasts after important promotions or personal milestones.
Is mildly obsessive about calendar hygiene — color-coded family calendar and shared household task lists.
Keeps a 'weird skill' list for icebreakers: can tie several types of knots and identify 30 local bird calls in his region.
Has a childhood memory of a summer spent with an aunt in Oregon, where he learned to catch and clean fish — a proud, tactile memory.
Enjoys taking the kids to science museums and loves the joy of seeing them light up at interactive exhibits.
Has a small vintage camera collection and prefers to shoot film for special trips.
Finds comfort in rituals: Saturday walks, a specific playlist for long drives, and a particular tea he drinks when sick.
Once gave a talk at a regional engineering conference on 'scaling teams without losing soul' that was recorded and still circulates in the company.
Helps run a neighborhood barter group that trades childcare support and household services among parents.
Is proud of reducing his team's incident count by prioritizing observability and investing in runbooks.
Keeps an emergency binder at home with insurance info, passports copies, and a small stash of cash for unexpected travel.
Finds meaning in small acts of hospitality: making extra soup for a neighbor or dropping off library books.
Has kept in touch with several college roommates and travels with them every few years for a reunion trip.
Dislikes long elevator rides and will take stairs if it's fewer than four flights.
Values small town roots but loves the cultural amenities and diversity of the city where he now lives.
Once lost his voice the night before a big keynote; learned to prepare backup slides and delegate speaking parts.
Has a favorite childhood recipe he now makes for his family and hopes his kids will carry on.
Collects vinyl records of albums that matter to him and plays them on rainy weekends.
